metadata.description: Energy efficiency rebound effect configuration (Jevons Paradox)
metadata.methodology: Based on IEA Energy Efficiency reports and academic literature on rebound effects
sources: IEA Energy Efficiency 2024 - Rebound effect estimates
Sorrell et al. 2009 - Empirical estimates of direct rebound effects
Greening et al. 2000 - Energy efficiency and consumption
Brockway et al. 2017 - Energy efficiency and economic growth
metadata.key_insight: Efficiency improvements lead to 5-10% increased consumption (Jevons Paradox). We model this conservatively at 7%.

description_of_global_rate: 7% of efficiency savings are consumed through increased demand (IEA estimate, conservative mid-range)

notes.transport: 10% - More efficient vehicles lead to more driving (lower cost per mile)
notes.residential_heating: 20% - More efficient heating allows higher thermostat settings (comfort effect)
notes.residential_cooling: 15% - Similar to heating, efficiency enables more AC use
notes.residential_appliances: 5% - Lower rebound for discrete appliances (TV, fridge, etc.)
notes.industrial: 5% - Limited rebound in industrial sector (production driven by demand, not energy cost)
notes.commercial: 8% - Moderate rebound in commercial buildings (similar to residential)

rationale.jevons_paradox: William Stanley Jevons (1865) observed that improved coal efficiency in steam engines led to increased coal consumption, not decreased. The same effect applies to modern energy systems.
rationale.direct_rebound: Lower energy cost per unit service → increased consumption of that service (e.g., more driving with efficient car)
rationale.indirect_rebound: Energy savings → more disposable income → increased consumption of other goods/services (which require energy)
rationale.economy_wide_rebound: Efficiency improvements → economic growth → overall energy demand increase
rationale.net_effect: IEA estimates 5-10% direct rebound for most efficiency gains. Including indirect effects, total rebound could be 10-30%. We use 7% (conservative, direct + partial indirect).

application_in_model.method: Reduce calculated useful energy by rebound_rate
application_in_model.example: If theoretical efficiency gives 100 EJ useful, with 7% rebound: 100 × (1 - 0.07) = 93 EJ net useful energy
application_in_model.interpretation: 7% of efficiency savings are 'taken back' through increased consumption
application_in_model.KNOWN_LIMITATION_v2.4: Current implementation applies rebound as a blanket 7% reduction to ALL useful energy, rather than only to efficiency improvements over time. This is methodologically simplified. Proper implementation would track historical efficiency gains and apply rebound only to the delta. However, this simplified approach provides a conservative estimate and avoids overestimating useful energy. Future versions should implement time-series tracking of efficiency improvements for more accurate rebound modeling.

validation.iea_estimate: IEA reports 5-10% direct rebound for typical efficiency improvements
validation.academic_consensus: Sorrell et al. (2009) meta-analysis: direct rebound 10-30% for transport, 0-50% for heating (wide range)
validation.our_choice: 7% is conservative mid-range, accounts for direct + partial indirect rebound

historical_context.global_efficiency_improvement: Global energy system efficiency improved from ~30% (1965) to ~37% (2024)
historical_context.expected_energy_reduction: If no rebound, this should reduce energy demand by ~19%
historical_context.actual_energy_growth: Global energy consumption increased 3.5x from 1965 to 2024
historical_context.explanation: Economic growth + rebound effect >> efficiency gains. Our model captures efficiency accurately by including 7% rebound in the useful energy calculation.

note_on_disable: Set 'disable_rebound' to true or set global_rebound_rate to 0.0 to calculate theoretical useful energy without rebound effects (for sensitivity analysis)
